title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Loyola University Chicago in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was a little crazy for an admin position. First, there was a phone interview, about 30 minutes, during which I was told that I was perfect for the job and that there were not many applicants. 

After a ton of follow-ups due to not hearing back in the promised time period, another interview was scheduled via Zoom. It was actually three, 30-minute Zoom interviews with three separate people, one of them being an HR person. Again, I was told I was perfect for the position, but they were "still conducting interviews" and would hear back by the end of the next week. When I did not hear back, I followed up. I got a reply a few hours later saying that an offer had been accepted by another candidate. 

Note for Loyola: It does not make sense to do a total of two hours of interviews and have someone speak to HR about benefits and stuff when you have no intention of hiring that person. It also doesn't make sense to tell someone repeatedly that they are perfect for a position and then not select them. Consider eliminating the HR portion of interviews and doing two interviews max, not four, until you are certain of who you want to hire.
Interview Questions: What do you know about Loyola University?

title: Senior Service Desk Applications Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Loyola University Chicago in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: Position was initially posted in March of 2020, but was affected by COVID and was placed on hold until mid-July.  Interview process consisted on three rounds - one with the hiring manager; one with the Desktop Support manager; and one with a director of the IT department.  Each interview round seemed to take forever between rounds, with little feedback.  Each round focused on my customer service, technical, and personality skills.  The Desktop Support manager I found to be very jovial - they had a warm personality and a sense of humor.  The Director of the department I found to be very personable as well.  After the final round, it look 5 weeks, and several emails sent to management to receive final candidate feedback.  Finally, after the 5th email status check, I received a canned response from the hiring manager with quotation marks left on the front and the end of the email message body.  Suffice to say that if I did not continue to follow up with the institution, that no final decision would have been relayed to me.  This practice is extremely sad concerning the current job climate that we are in.  I can handle hearing that I did not receive an offer.  I find it lazy and ignorant for organizations to abide by a bad habit such as ignoring the un-chosen candidate base when a final candidate is chosen.
Interview Questions: Describe a time where you had to juggle multiple projects.  How did you prioritize your work, and what was the overall outcome?

title: Researcher Interview

After interviews, they took about 3-4 weeks to make a final decision.  When following-up, the hiring manager was the only one who was responsive; not HR.  Unfortunately, Loyola is plagued with politics and arrogance; not a welcoming feeling for new candidates looking for employment.   Even when I visited the office, I sensed a toxic environment.   Being objective, while Loyola is a prestigious institution and working here would look great on your resume, they are disorganized.    I really feel like I dodged a bullet by not working here. found job on linkedin, applied online through their career website, maybe 1-2 weeks later received generically-worded e-mail from current admin asst saying they were 'impressed with my background/experience and if i'd be free for phone interview. didn't state who phone interview would be with, but it ended up being a 3-way phone call which was quite awkward because callers didn't speak clearly and both interviewers didn't seem to know who would talk next. they also said that they have had a lot of very qualified candidates "including yourself", so tell them what I can bring to the table. it was a lot of fluffy talk. received e-mail from an hr manager maybe 2 weeks later that position had been filled. i wasn't surprised. i don't think i would have been a good fit for the position either, so it worked out very well!

i initially thought phone interview would be a simple phone screen so I didn't prepare in-depth questions to ask them since I'd ask them later on, but I suppose each department does their process differently.

btw, i checked back on their website and noticed that the new hire is a lot older than me and seems to have made a long career out of administrative assistant so i guess this job fits their career path more than for mine.
Interview Questions: how did you find out about this job?

title: Student Worker Into Full Time Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Loyola University Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The phone and in-person interviews seemed to go well overall. I had recently graduated from LUC but worked for the same department I was applying to in the university as a student worker for four years. My former supervisor recommended that I apply to stay on full time after graduation, and I did so. The interview seemed to go well, and I was complimented several times by various people on my previous service as a student worker. I left feeling very good about things and was told that a decision could be made by the end of the current week. Three weeks later, I still had yet to hear back despite contacting both Loyola HR and the department I had interviewed with. Finally, I got an extremely generic and brief form rejection letter by email from HR after serving as a student employee of the department for my whole undergraduate career and being recommended by my supervisors. It was disappointing that I was not offered the position, but you don't get every job you apply for. As an alum and former member of that department's team for multiple years, what upset me most was feeling as if my candidacy and relationship with the department was ended so informally. This was not the "care for the whole person" I had grown accustomed to from Loyola. Unfortunately, I now have a very bitter taste in my mouth towards my undergraduate institution due to how this process was handled overall.
Interview Questions: Extremely generic interview questions directly related to the role I was applying for.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Loyola University Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2010
Interview Descriptions:
Like any academic institution, my experience with the interview process for a staff position at Loyola was fairly drawn out.  The longest gap was between actually applying and hearing back, which was around 6 weeks.  The first round was a panel interview, followed by a second round with another panel & two 1:1 interviews.  There was a holiday in between rounds so again response was drawn out a little, but after my second round interview I actually got an offer a day or two before I thought I might.  That was a great feeling.  

The best advice I would give to someone interviewing at Loyola, or any university/college, is to be patient and show as much enthusiasm as you can muster.  These are popular positions to apply to, so if you stand out enough to hear back be grateful, even if there is a long gap between applying and interviewing.  And once you interview, really make the most of it.
Interview Questions: How would you convince us that you're the best candidate for this opening?
